text: the attacks this week in Baghdad against
its prominent church and a series of
assaults across the capital were some of
the worst violence in Baghdad since 2003
they come in a precarious time in the
capital across Iraq they underlined a
deep sense of anticipation deep sense of
anxiety over the direction of the
country but in a broader sense they
illustrate the worry that this
institutions of the very state are
incapable of coping with what has been a
persistent problem in Iraq since 2003
that's violence the attacks don't come
in a vacuum in Baghdad nor is the
violence the same as we've often seen in
past weeks in past months the attack
against the church was against one of
the most prominent churches in the city
and it underlined a sense of siege among
Christians here many of whom have left
since the invasion in 2003 but in
conversations across the capital what's
perhaps most striking is the way that
people don't cast blame against any one
individual or any one politician but
rather the entire class of politicians
there's a growing sense of a gulf
between the ruling class and basically
those they rule and there's a sense that
political class isn't able to cope with
the problems ahead they're mired in
their own negotiations over power and
while those negotiations go on the
situation in the streets gets worse
there's perhaps something of an irony in
all this at a time that American
attention toward Iraq is flagging the
country itself is dealing with some of
its most decisive moments the violence
the deadlock the loss of faith in the
government is making for one of the
racks biggest crises since 2003
